Others

Documents & Templates

Tools

  • Messaging and Communication: Skype, Slack
  • Video Conferencing: BlueJeans, Zoom TUM
  • Project Management: Monday
  • Reference Management: Paperpile, Mendeley, BibDesk.
  • LaTeX Editors: TeXstudio, Overleaf, and ShareLaTeX
  • Code Management: Git, PyCharm, Jupyter Notebook, Google Colab
  • Deign illustrative figures: Adobe Illustrator, Microsoft Visio, MS SmartArt Graphics
  • Specific Purposes: ConvNets, Medical Imaging,
  • Data Visualization: Plotly

Calendars

  • Feel free to subscribe to Albarqouni Lab’s calendar. Most of the conferences and deadlines are available here.

item.title: Datasets
item.description:
Guidelines

You came up with a nice idea and would like to validate it as a Proof-of-Concept (PoC), then you should validate it first on one of the benchmarking datasets:

  • FedML: A Research Library and Benchmark for Federated Machine Learning
  • LEAF: Benchmark for FL
  • Benchmarking SSFL
  • Real World Image Benchmark FL
  • Benchmarking FL on Clinical Datasets

Once you have a valid PoC, then you could investigate one of the below use-cases. If you are interested to create your own use-case, then please do the following:

  1. Find the database that meets your requirements
  2. Get Shadi’s signature on the corresponding forms, if necessary.
  3. Download the dataset, save it in a secure folder, and add it to the list below
  4. Write the data loader. Please follow the data split (Train/Val/Test) or K-fold CV that appeared in the STOA papers. Please add whatever available meta-information, e.g. Age, Gender, Scanner, Location, …etc.
  5. Store the signed forms, datasets, readme, dataloader, and the Hdf5 in this folder TBD.
  6. Once you design your use-case, append it to the table below.

Use-Cases

Use-Cases Datasets # of Clients Task Related Works Hdf5
Breast Cancer Histology Imaging 5 WSI Classification MICCAI-DCL Paper

ML Datasets:

  • MLData
  • UCI ML Repository
  • VisualData
  • CMU Library

CV Datasets:

  • Federated Street
  • Blackbirds dataset?

Clinical Datasets:

Tabular Datasets

  • Medical Information Matry for Intensive Care
  • PhysioNet ECG Datasets

Histology Imaging

  • <<<<<<< HEAD CAMELYON’16
  • CAMELYON’17
    • ======= CAMELYON'16
  • CAMELYON'17
    • >>>>>>> 4c50658... updates

  • IMA205 Challenge
  • ISIC 2016
  • ISCI 2017
  • EDRA, EDRA-2
  • References: Nature Paper, CVPR Paper, Moles Data

Chest X-ray

Tuberculosis Datasets

  • TB CXR India
  • TB CXR Shenzhen
  • TB CXR Montgomery
  • Reference: NIH Paper

Other databases:

If you couldn’t find the right dataset, have a look at these repos.:

  • The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA)
  • The Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA)
  • UK BioBank
  • Grand-Challenges
  • Google Dataset Search

item.title: Research
item.description:
Here are some more tips for getting started with your PhD:

Seminars, Reading Groups, and Meetups (8%)

Apart from our group meeting and the internal journal club, it is highly recommended that you join one of these seminars:

Deep Learning

  • Deep Learning: Classics and Trends
  • Harvard Machine Learning Theory
  • Munich Computer Vision & Medical Image Analysis Meetup
  • ICB/H.AI Seminars – TBA

Federated Learning

  • Federated Learning Seminar
  • Federated Learning in Healthcare –Internal one

Courses, Tutorials and Workshops (5%)

It is part of your work to cultivate yourself with the foundation of Deep Learning. This would help you in contributing to the Teaching and Training activities.

Courses and Tutorials in Deep Learning

  • Deep Learning with Pytorch
  • MIT Deep Learning and AI Lectures
  • CNNs for Visual Recognition
  • NLP with Deep Learning
  • Deep Unsupervised Learning
  • Bayesian Deep Learning
  • Bayesian Deep Learning 101
  • Deep Multi-Task and Meta-Learning
  • Geometric Deep Learning
  • Interpretable ML for CV

Workshops in Federated Learning

  • <<<<<<< HEAD ECMLPKDD Workshop’20
  • ICML Workshop’20
  • NeurIP Workshop’19
  • MICCAI DCL’20 Workshop
    • ======= ECMLPKDD Workshop'20
  • ICML Workshop'20
  • NeurIP Workshop'19
  • MICCAI DCL'20 Workshop
    • >>>>>>> 4c50658... updates

Summer Schools (2%)

You are highly recommended to attend one of the summer schools at the first few years of your PhD. Please discuss this with Shadi.

  • Machine Learning Summer Schools
  • Medical Imaging Summer School – Biennial
  • International Computer Vision Summer School
  • Schools endorsed by MICCAI and BMVA are welcome.

Mentorship (3%)

You are strongly encouraged to mentor Bachelor and Master students. If you have a nice idea, please discuss it with Shadi, and write it down on this template, before you announce it on our student webpage. Alternatively, you can participate in grand-challenges as well.

Grand-Challenges (3%)

You are also recommended to participate in Grand-Challenges with your students. Interdisciplinary Projects offered at TU Munich is the perfect fit here. Most of the time, a publication with +30 co-authors ends up in a highly-impacted journal with a lot of citations. You only need to be on the top 10 on the leaderboard.

  • Federated Tumor Segmentation (FeTS) Initiative
  • Grand-Challenges in Medical Imaging

Reading Lists (30%)

Reading lists on Federated Learning

  • Awesome FL Papers
  • IEEE ICASSP Special Session
  • Semi-Supervised FL
  • Fully Supervised FL
  • Unsupervised FL

Reading lists on Deep Learning

  • TBD

Reading lists on Deep Learning with Medical Imaging

  • TBD

Coding (30%)

Resources and Guidelines for reading, writing and submitting Papers

One of the first steps in conducting your research is reading literature. However, how to read, quickly, efficiently, and seriously, a scientific paper?. The questions is addressed in the following resources:

  • How to Read a Paper
  • How to Read a Research Paper
  • How to Read Scientific Papers Quickly & Efficiently
  • How to (seriously) read a scientific paper

Paper (10%)

  1. Read the following resourses:
    • Publish like a pro
    • How to write a first class paper
    • Heuristics for Scientific Writing
    • Guidelines for Wirting a Good NIPS Paper
  2. Read carefully the “Authors Guidelines” appaared in the corresponding conference’s or journal’s website. For example, pay attention on the format, page limit, anonymity, reference style, and special requirements.
  3. TBC

Blog (2%)

TBD –Biweekly/Monthly

Review (5%)

TBD

  • How to write a good review
  • Writing reviews for systems conferences

Rebuttal

TBD

  • How to write a rebuttal letter

Proposal (5%)

TBD

Poetntial Journals and Conferences

It is highly recommended that you submit your novel work to one of the top-tier conferences, and then extend the work to a journal article. Here you can see a few potential journals and confereces. Please let Shadi knows if you have other suggestions.

Journals

Ordered by the Impact Factor (2019)

  • IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON PATTERN ANALYSIS AND MACHINE INTELLIGENCE 17.861
  • MEDICAL IMAGE ANALYSIS 11.148
  • IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON IMAGE PROCESSING, 9.340
  • IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, 8.793
  • IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON MEDICAL IMAGING 6.685
  • IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics 5.223
  • IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON BIOMEDICAL ENGINEERING 4.424
  • ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE IN MEDICINE 4.383
  • COMPUTERIZED MEDICAL IMAGING AND GRAPHICS 3.750
  • COMPUTER VISION AND IMAGE UNDERSTANDING 3.121
  • IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON PARALLEL AND DISTRIBUTED SYSTEMS 2.600
  • IET Image Processing 1.995
  • Nature Machine Intelligence

Conferences

Conferences ordered by top-tier ranking.

Machine Learning

NeurIPS, ICLR, ICML, ECML-PkDD

Computer Vision

CVPR, ICCV, ECCV– Biennial, BMVC, WACV

Medical Imaging

MICCAI, IPMI – Biennial, MIDL, ISBI

Workshops

<<<<<<< HEAD ECMLPKDD Workshop’20, ======= ECMLPKDD Workshop'20, >>>>>>> 4c50658... updates Ml4H, NeurIPS NewInML Workshop MICCAI DCL Workshop DAGM, BVM

Where you are

For more PhD Comics, you can cisit this website.

item.title: Coding
item.description:
Guidelines

You came up with a nice idea and would like to code a Proof-of-Concept (PoC), please follow this guidelines:

  1. Create a private repository with detailed readme.md file at Albarqouni Lab. Git.
  2. Make sure you list all dependencies in requirements.yaml
  3. Write all your configurations, e.g. where you retrieve/store the logs and data, in a single JSON file config.json.
  4. Caution: Avoid hard-coding paths or hyper-parameters. Make sure you have a configuration file for every single experiment.
  5. Try to structure your code similar to the example below; dataloader, mains, trainers/optimizers, logs, and utils.
  6. Make sure you have a well-written documentation for your code.
  7. Provide CLI scripts as well as Python Notebooks, if possible.
  8. In case you want to make the repo. publicly available, get Shadi’s approval first in case he wants to file a patent.
  9. Make sure you acknowledge any code your borrowed, and make it clear in the Disclaimer section.
  10. Add the right license, e.g. CC BY-NC-SA 4.0
  11. Push the paper on arXiv and add it to the citation section.
  12. Make sure you adhere to the ML Code Completeness Checklist before you appned your work to the Codes section.

Here is a good example from our recent work on Unsupervised Anomaly Detection.

  .
  Framework/
  â
  âââ readme.md 
  âââ Notebooks.ipynb - Jupyter notebook to work on Google Colab
  âââ run.py - execute to run in commandline
  âââ config.json - holds configuration where to store and retrieve data and logs
  âââ requirements.yaml - list the dependencies required to run the model
  â
  âââ data_loaders/ - Definition of dataloaders
  â   âââ Brain.py
  â   âââ ChestXray.py
  â   âââ ...
  â
  âââ logs/ - default directory for storing tensorboard logs
  â
  âââ mains/ - Main files to train each architecture
  â   âââ main_cnn.py
  â   âââ ...
  â
  âââ model/ - Architecture definitions
  â   âââ cnn.py
  â   âââ ...
  â
  âââ trainers/ - trainers including definition of loss functions, and metrics
  â   âââ cnn.py
  â   âââ ...
  â  
  âââ utils/ - utility functions
      âââ util.py
      âââ ...

Benchmarking FL

  • FedML: A Research Library and Benchmark for Federated Machine Learning
  • LEAF: Benchmark for FL
  • Benchmarking SSFL
  • Real World Image Benchmark FL
  • Benchmarking FL on Clinical Datasets

Frameworks

It is highly recommended that you code in PyTorch along with the Medical Open Network for AI (MONAI), if possible. Most of the available FL frameworks are listed below with a comparison of their features and functionalities.

  • FedML –promising!
  • FedBioMed
  • LEAF
  • PySyft
  • TenorFlow Federated (TFF)
  • FATE
  • NVIDIA Clara
  • IBM Federated Learning Framework

Code Tutorial

You can find here a few coding examples on different datasets:

  • FedML Tutorials
  • TensorFlow Federated Tutorial
  • FL on MNIST with PyTorch & PySyft
  • FL on MedNIST with MONAI, PyTorch, and FedBioMed
  • FL on 3D Segmentation with MONAI
  • IBM Federated Learning Tutorial
  • NVIDIA Clara Train Documentation

Playgrounds

Interested to get more insights on DL, Optimization, Interpretability and Visualization! Have a look at these amazing playgrounds:

  • Interactive Tools for ML, DL, and Math
  • How to use t-SNE Effectively
  • Exploring Bayesian Optimization
  • Communicating with Interactive Articles
